Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History: Preservation of Carnegie Museum of Natural History's Herpetology Collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will improve the security, preservation, and accessibility of the Carnegie Museum of Natural History Herpetological Collection, a world-class resource of over 235,000 specimens. This collection includes large historical holdings from areas that have undergone drastic environmental change or may face important change in the future. Recent research citing the collection exemplifies how new and unpredicted scientific paradigms, environmental issues, and technological advances require the existence of extensive and accessible historical scientific collections. Genetics, molecular phylogenetics, museomics, biomechanics, global change, emerging diseases, and invasive species are research areas for which specimens from this collection have recently been used. Based on recommendations from recent assessments that identified a number of urgent challenges affecting the collection and its related data, Carnegie Museum of Natural History has developed an extensive plan to preserve and increase access to the collection, ensuring that this important resource is sustained and able to support research for generations to come.

Ranking tenth among US collections of its kind, the Herpetology Collection at Carnegie Museum of Natural History spans more than 100 years of scientific collecting in 170 countries. It includes 148 holotypes and 2,007 paratypes (specimens of special scientific and historic significance used in the original species descriptions), specimens of six extinct and 78 critically endangered species, and one of the world's largest turtle collections. Through this award, Carnegie Museum of Natural History will: a) optimize storage space to improve curation and access and mitigate preservation risks due to overcrowding and suboptimal containers; b) digitize vouchered archival data related to specific specimens, providing vital context for the collection; c) accession and catalog ca. 12,000 specimens, georeference locality data, and make data and images of holotypes and paratypes digitally accessible; d) update taxonomy throughout the Section and reorganize the collection accordingly; e) enhance the public's appreciation of the value of collections and research by developing new collections-based programs and exhibits. Ensuring the long-term preservation and availability of the Section's specimens and related data is key for supporting future research efforts. Likewise, digitizing important archival records will expand the relevance of the collection for studies in ecology, systematics, conservation, and the history of natural history collections. Updating taxonomy and georeferencing additional records will enhance the precision of biodiversity data, improving usefulness to the global research community. In addition, collaborative planning will lead to the implementation of new educational programming and two new museum exhibits designed to enhance the public's appreciation of the value of collections for research and increase understanding of the collection's importance in the public's day-to-day life. Project results are available on line (www.carnegiemnh.org/projects/alcohol-house), and data will be shared and made available through iDigBio (www.idigbio.org), VertNet, and the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carnegie Museum of Natural History’s Herpetology collection—the tenth largest herpetological collection in the United States—comprises approximately 235,000 specimens housed in a historic structure known as the “Alcohol House” for the fluid-preserved collections that are stored inside. Recent assessments of the collection and collection space identified a number of urgent issues that threatened the long-term preservation of the collection: the storage space within the Alcohol House lacked efficient organization, and preservation conditions were suboptimal; archival data, including documents and slides, lacked proper storage and were not digitized; there was a backlog of uncatalogued specimens and many records that required georeferencing; and the taxonomy of the collection needed to be updated to correspond with advances in amphibian and reptile systematics. This project set out to both remedy these issues and create engaging, visitor-facing experiences designed to communicate and emphasize the importance of the long-term preservation of important biological collections.

The project yielded:

  • Optimized collection storage space: Floor space on the second and third floors of the Alcohol House was reconfigured and reorganized with improved shelving capacity to alleviate overcrowding and accommodate future growth, repositioned and rearranged specimen tanks, and newly-installed fire-proof cabinets for holotype specimens (single specimens upon which the description and name of a new species is based).
  • Enhanced preservation methods throughout the collection: Throughout the collection, all ineffective and outdated glass jars and gaskets were replaced.
  • Imaged and digitized holotype and paratype specimens (specimens the help define what the scientific name of a species represents, but are not the holotype): Prior to 2016, no specimen images were available to the public. Currently, all 156 of the collection’s holotypes are imaged, and those images are available on iDigBio.org. The paratype specimen collection (an additional 2,007 specimens) was also imaged and uploaded to iDigBio.org. 
  • Preserved and digitized vouchered archival data: All 51 drawers and 178 linear feet of archival material—including accession data, correspondence, departmental files, field notes, and science notebooks—were reorganized and electronically scanned.
  • Accessioned backlog of specimens: Prior to beginning this project, there were approximately 170,290 catalog entries for the collection. Of these, nearly 40,000 entries lacked latitude/longitude data, and many included incomplete data. Currently, all available data for catalog entries are incorporated, totaling 182,606 specimen entries.
  • Updated taxonomy: All the required taxonomic nomenclature updates of anuran, salamander, saurian, snake, crocodilian, and caecilian specimens were completed and are reflected in both database entries and specimen jars.
  • Enhanced scientific communication and exhibition: This project yielded a large-scale digital interactive that is permanently housed in the museum’s Discovery Basecamp gallery. The interactive comprises one large vertical 65” infrared touchscreen and two touch displays embedded in a table that was once used in the museum's herpetology collection. Seamlessly blending authentic specimens with state-of-the-art technology, the kiosk creates a platform for visitors to explore 70 real specimens hand selected from the museum’s herpetological collection. The museum’s exhibitions department also designed, fabricated, and installed a large case to house a mix of specimens and artifacts that will support tours of the Alcohol House. Specimens and objects are now on display and will be used to orient the visitor to the collections space and to tell the story of building and maintaining a fluid collection.

Now complete, this project has dramatically enhanced the preservation of and access to a major US herpetological collection that includes large historical holdings from areas that suffered deep environmental change (e.g., US and the Caribbean) or may undergo important change in the future (e.g., tropical forests of Africa, the Amazon, and South-East Asia). Recent research derived from the collection already exemplifies how the emergence of new and unpredicted scientific paradigms, environmental issues, and technological advances require the existence of extensive and accessible historical collections. Conservation genetics, molecular phylogenetics, biomechanics, global change, emerging diseases, gut microbiomes, and invasive species, are significant subject areas to which the Section’s collections recently contributed.
